text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A square piece of paper is folded once along a straight line, and a single hole is punched through both layers.

When the paper is unfolded, which of the following patterns of holes is impossible to create? 

A) Two holes that form a horizontal line parallel to the bottom edge of the paper
B) Two holes that form a vertical line parallel to the left edge of the paper
C) Two holes that form a diagonal line from the top-left to the bottom-right of the paper
D) Three holes forming a right triangle
E) Two holes with different distances from the center of the paper 

 Solution: 
<think>
Alright, so I have this problem about folding a square piece of paper and punching a hole through both layers.
Then, when you unfold it, there are certain patterns of holes that are impossible.
I need to figure out which one is impossible.
Let me think through this step by step.
First, the paper is square, so let's imagine it as a standard square with edges of equal length.
When it's folded once along a straight line, that fold can be either a horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line.
The fold will create two layers of paper on top of each other.
Punching a single hole through both layers means that when you unfold the paper, you'll have two holes that are mirror images across the fold line.
So, let's consider each option one by one.
Option A: Two holes forming a horizontal line parallel to the bottom edge.
Hmm, if the fold is horizontal, then punching a hole along the fold would create two holes aligned horizontally.
If the fold is vertical, punching a hole would create a vertical line of two holes.
Wait, but if the fold is diagonal, would that create a horizontal line? No, because a diagonal fold would mirror the hole across the diagonal.
So, to get a horizontal line, the fold must be horizontal.
So, yes, it's possible by folding horizontally and punching along the fold.
Option B: Two holes forming a vertical line parallel to the left edge.
Similar to the above, if we fold the paper vertically, then punching a hole through both layers would create two holes vertically aligned.
So, this is also possible.
Option C: Two holes forming a diagonal line from top-left to bottom-right.
If the fold is along the diagonal from top-left to bottom-right, then punching a hole through both layers would create two holes along that diagonal.
So, yes, this is possible too.
Option D: Three holes forming a right triangle.
Hmm, now this is more interesting.
If we have three holes forming a right triangle, that means we have two holes on one side and one on the other, forming a right angle.
But how can folding and punching create three holes? Each fold can only create two holes at most because you punch through both layers.
So, if you fold once, you can only have two holes.
To get three holes, you might need to fold more than once, but the problem says it's folded once.
So, maybe it's impossible to have three holes forming a right triangle with just one fold.
Option E: Two holes with different distances from the center.
Let's see.
If the fold is not through the center, then the two holes will be at different distances from the center.
If the fold is through the center, both holes would be equidistant from the center.
So, to have different distances, the fold must not pass through the center.
Therefore, this is possible.
So, based on this reasoning, Option D seems impossible because you can only have two holes with a single fold.
To get three holes forming a right triangle would require more than one fold, which isn't allowed in this problem.
Wait, but let me double-check.
If I fold the paper once, punch two holes, then unfold, I can only have two holes.
If I want three holes, I might have to fold it in a specific way, but I don't think a single fold can create three holes.
Each fold can only mirror the hole across the fold line, so it's either creating one hole or two mirrored holes.
Therefore, three holes aren't possible with a single fold.
Yes, that makes sense.
So, Option D is impossible.

</think>

The impossible pattern is D.
